repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Fourth Programmatic Social Reform
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Programmatic Social Reform
            Project (PSRL IV) for Peru had a satisfactory outcome, is
            likely to be sustainable, and had a substantial development
            impact. Bank and Borrower performances were satisfactory.
            Several lessons drawn from the three earlier PSRLs are
            reconfirmed in this retrospective assessment of the four
            loans: First, In addition to the "mechanical"
            aspects of institution-building-information gathering and
            analysis, new hardware and software systems, modernization
            of skills, reorganization of work flow -- reforms that
            realign public expenditures and programs, as well as
            increase transparency and broaden participation in
            government decision-making and implementation, often require
            profound changes in social attitudes and threaten, or are
            perceived to threaten, powerful entrenched interests.
            Consequently, preparation costs are likely to be high; the
            process and the commitment required of those who would
            support it is likely to be long; and confidence in the
            sustainability of the reforms initiated may take
            considerably longer and will almost certainly need continued
            financial and technical support. Second, the PSRL proves an
            effective instrument for maintaining a constructive dialogue
            and supporting a coherent and focused policy agenda. It has
            bridged two Governments and several changes of Cabinet. It
            has also allowed the flexibility needed to respond to new
            initiatives (e.g., the workfare program and pension reform),
            to adapt to a changing political context (viz.,
            decentralization), to develop and refine targets and
            performance indicators, to initiate and incorporate the
            results of pilot reform experiments, to adjust Bank support
            to the evolving performance of economic and social policies,
            and to beat a tactical retreat and seek other approaches and
            means of support when certain components proved infeasible.
            Third, the central role of the Ministry of Economic and
            Finance in the negotiation of the social agenda and in its
            implementation pushed the reforms forward. However,
            centering program design, coordination, and loan
            negotiations in the Finance Ministry weakens the line
            ministries responsible for implementation as diminishes the
            commitment level of the respective ministers. Fourth, strong
            monitoring and evaluation systems are essential.  Fifth, the
            open and participatory fashion in which the PSRL agenda was
            formulated helped to build consensus both inside and outside
            the government. Sixth, PSRL's support of greater
            transparency and participation in the setting of social
            priorities and in the monitoring of government response to
            them has made an important contribution.

repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Fourth Programmatic Social Reform
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Programmatic Social Reform
            Loan Project (PSRL IV) is the fourth and final stage of a
            four-year program in Peru, which uses a Programmatic
            Development Policy Loan instrument to support reforms aimed
            at increasing access, transparency, and efficiency in
            service provision.  The main objective of PSRL has been,
            since the beginning of the program in 2001, to support
            Peru's medium term social policy reforms. PSRL IV is
            focused on consolidating these reforms and increasing their
            sustainability into the future.  It will support efforts to
            complete and consolidate reforms in five areas: social
            expenditures management; redesign, targeting, and
            administration of social protection programs; access to
            health services; access and efficiency in education; and
            transparency and accountability in the social sectors.
